text.p: These are the leading stories in the Kenyan press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Pressure mounts on government to stop violence by youth from ruling Kenya African National Union (KANU) and group calling itself "The old man's army".
- Senior police officer critically hurt and his gun confiscated on outskirts of Nairobi while pursuing car hijackers.
- National Council of Churches of Kenya condemns selective armed cattle rustling targeted at particular community in Rift Valley.
- KANU scheduled to give detailed proposal on constitutional reforms this week.
- President Moi defends security forces against accusations of human rights violations.

- National Convention Executive Committee will represent opposition and other lobby groups pushing for constitutional reforms in expected dialogue with government, official opposition leader Michael Kijana Wamalwa says.
- Cross-section of leaders maintain constitutional reforms should be handled by parliament.
- Moi says burning flag is height of unpatriotic behaviour.
- Finance Minister Mudavadi says Kenya enjoys warm relations with donors.
- Burundian parties which attended peace talks in Rome will take part in talks in Arusha led by former Tanzanian president Julius Nyerere.
- Ugandan parliamentarians preparing motion proposing amalgamation of some ministries that will reduce number of cabinet ministers and cut government spending.
